description.name: description
description.value:
Here is code:

$db = Zend_Db::factory('Pdo_Mysql', array(
'host' => '****',
'username' => '****',
'password' => '****',
'dbname' => 'test_db'
));
$result = $db->fetchAll('SELECT * FROM bugs_products WHERE bug_id = ?', 1);

Zend_Debug::dump($result);

Zend_Debug::dump($db->describeTable('bugs_products'));

Here is output:

array(1) {
[0] => array(5) {
["bug_id"] => string(1) "1"
["product_id"] => string(1) "0"
["bugs_products"] => string(1) "4"
["test_db"] => string(1) "5"
["def"] => string(1) "6" }
}

array(6) {
["bug_id"] => array(14) {

}
["col4"] => array(14) {

}

================
Just to be clear:

This is query result:

array(1) {
  [0] => array(5) {
    ["bug_id"] => string(1) "1"
    ["product_id"] => string(1) "0"
    ["bugs_products"] => string(1) "4"
    ["test_db"] => string(1) "5"
    ["def"] => string(1) "6"
  }
}

This is table columns:

array(6) {
  [0] => string(6) "bug_id"
  [1] => string(10) "product_id"
  [2] => string(4) "name"
  [3] => string(4) "col4"
  [4] => string(4) "col5"
  [5] => string(4) "col6"
}

Why the query result don't match the table definition? Is there anything wrong with code? Or is it a bug?


Hopefully there is someone could help me!

Thanks

value.name: Zend_Db
value.description: interfaces, APIs, and adapters for various third-party data stores

value.body: My guess would be that every Zend_Db issue is a 'zend_db issue'.

This is not an issue, Zend_Db returns exactly that what you asked it for.

PS: Please don't abuse the issue tracker as support system, use the mailing list or IRC for those questions.

Table bugs_products has 6 columns:
    "bug_id" 
    "product_id" 
    "name" 
    "col4" 
    "col5" 
    "col6"

The query is:
   SELECT * FROM bugs_products WHERE bug_id = 1

And return result:
array(1) {
[0] => array(5) { 
       ["bug_id"] => string(1) "1" 
       ["product_id"] => string(1) "0" 
       ["bugs_products"] => string(1) "4" 
       ["test_zend_db"] => string(1) "5" 
       ["def"] => string(1) "6" 
      }
}

The columns don't match. How could this happen?

BTW, I asked the questions in Zend Forums. Someone suggested me to ask here.
Thanks

Here are my other findings:

It seems if the table has only two columns, it will be good.
But if it has 3 or more columns:
- the first two columns will be correct.
- the third one will be using <tablename>
- the fourth will be using <schemaname>
- the fifth will be ['def']

And once the table has 7 or more columns, it will stop working (the error "CGI/FastCGI has stopped working" message)
BTW, I am using Zend Stutio 7.
